page.title: Domestic responses to the 2011 Egyptian revolution

rev.comment: /* Mediajihad: censorship and circumvention */ image added
rev.diff:
Line 308: Line 308:
==Mediajihad: censorship and circumvention==
==Mediajihad: censorship and circumvention==
<!--International reactions to the 2011 Egyptian protest links to this section-->
<!--International reactions to the 2011 Egyptian protest links to this section-->
â
[[File:Unplug-mubarak.gif|thumb|A [[political cartoon]] by [[Carlos Latuff]] depicting Hosni Mubarak unplugging Egypt from the Internet, and about to be disconnected himself in turn]]
+
[[File:Timeline of Communication Shutdown during the 2011 Egyptian Revolution.jpg|thumb|Timeline of Communication Shutdown during the 2011 Egyptian Revolution]]
[[Image:RadioCairoNetworkQuoteErrorUnquote.jpg|thumb|Radio Cairo DNS error.]]
[[Image:RadioCairoNetworkQuoteErrorUnquote.jpg|thumb|Radio Cairo DNS error.]]
Beginning on the first day of protests the Egyptian government censored most of the [[media of Egypt|media outlets inside Egypt]] and took measures to block social media websites<ref name="Facebook & Twitter Both Blocked in Egypt">{{cite web|author=Kessler, Sarah|url=http://mashable.com/2011/01/26/facebook-blocked-in-egypt/|title=Facebook & Twitter Both Blocked in Egypt|work=[[Mashable]]|date=2011-01-26|accessdate=2011-01-27}}</ref> which had helped protesters to spread news about the events on the ground. The success of the protests has been partly attributed to the involvement of tech ''savvy'' youth all over Egypt who were able to overcome the government blockades on social media. (As one activist succinctly tweeted during the protests, "âWe use Facebook to schedule the protests, Twitter to coordinate, and YouTube to tell the world.")<ref>http://www.miller-mccune.com/politics/the-cascading-effects-of-the-arab-spring-28575/</ref>
Beginning on the first day of protests the Egyptian government censored most of the [[media of Egypt|media outlets inside Egypt]] and took measures to block social media websites<ref name="Facebook & Twitter Both Blocked in Egypt">{{cite web|author=Kessler, Sarah|url=http://mashable.com/2011/01/26/facebook-blocked-in-egypt/|title=Facebook & Twitter Both Blocked in Egypt|work=[[Mashable]]|date=2011-01-26|accessdate=2011-01-27}}</ref> which had helped protesters to spread news about the events on the ground. The success of the protests has been partly attributed to the involvement of tech ''savvy'' youth all over Egypt who were able to overcome the government blockades on social media. (As one activist succinctly tweeted during the protests, "âWe use Facebook to schedule the protests, Twitter to coordinate, and YouTube to tell the world.")<ref>http://www.miller-mccune.com/politics/the-cascading-effects-of-the-arab-spring-28575/</ref>
Line 334: Line 334:
===Arrests, harassment, and assault of foreign journalists and NGOs===
===Arrests, harassment, and assault of foreign journalists and NGOs===
  +
[[File:Unplug-mubarak.gif|thumb|A [[political cartoon]] by [[Carlos Latuff]] depicting Hosni Mubarak unplugging Egypt from the Internet, and about to be disconnected himself in turn]]
On 3 February, journalists from a number of news organisations, including CNN, the Associated Press, CBS News, BBC News, Al Jazeera English, Danish TV2 News, Swiss television, Swedish [[SVT]] and Belgium's ''Le Soir'' newspaper, were reported assaulted, detained or otherwise obstructed.{{Citation needed|date=February 2011}} <!--<ref name="WSJ-journalists"/> this ref name was most likely orphaned during one of the upmteem drafts; possibly a section ported from main article? needs some research. hidden for now, (added cite tag) to avoid the ugly red message in citations-->The [[Committee to Protect Journalists]] said, on 3 February, that Mubarak had "unleashed an unprecedented and systematic attack on international media."<ref name="CPJ-3Feb">{{cite web|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://cpj.org/2011/02/mubarak-intensifies-press-attacks-with-assaults-de.php|title=Mubarak Intensifies Press Attacks with Assaults, Detentions|date=2011-02-03|publisher=[[Committee to Protect Journalists]]|accessdate=2011-02-03}}</ref> Security forces and pro-government gangs "hunted down journalists in their offices and hotels", preventing broadcast networks from airing live footage from Tahrir Square.<ref name="Kirkpatrick-journlists">{{registration required|date=February 2011}} {{cite news|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/02/04/world/middleeast/04journalists.html|title=Reporters in Egypt Under Broad Assault|author=Kirkpatrick, David D.; Goodman, J. David|date=2011-02-04|work=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=2011-02-03}}</ref>
On 3 February, journalists from a number of news organisations, including CNN, the Associated Press, CBS News, BBC News, Al Jazeera English, Danish TV2 News, Swiss television, Swedish [[SVT]] and Belgium's ''Le Soir'' newspaper, were reported assaulted, detained or otherwise obstructed.{{Citation needed|date=February 2011}} <!--<ref name="WSJ-journalists"/> this ref name was most likely orphaned during one of the upmteem drafts; possibly a section ported from main article? needs some research. hidden for now, (added cite tag) to avoid the ugly red message in citations-->The [[Committee to Protect Journalists]] said, on 3 February, that Mubarak had "unleashed an unprecedented and systematic attack on international media."<ref name="CPJ-3Feb">{{cite web|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://cpj.org/2011/02/mubarak-intensifies-press-attacks-with-assaults-de.php|title=Mubarak Intensifies Press Attacks with Assaults, Detentions|date=2011-02-03|publisher=[[Committee to Protect Journalists]]|accessdate=2011-02-03}}</ref> Security forces and pro-government gangs "hunted down journalists in their offices and hotels", preventing broadcast networks from airing live footage from Tahrir Square.<ref name="Kirkpatrick-journlists">{{registration required|date=February 2011}} {{cite news|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/02/04/world/middleeast/04journalists.html|title=Reporters in Egypt Under Broad Assault|author=Kirkpatrick, David D.; Goodman, J. David|date=2011-02-04|work=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=2011-02-03}}</ref>
